event.name: INLINE FUNCTION
event.problem: High overhead for frequent calls to a small function.
event.solution:
Enable compiler optimization, if not already enabled. If optimization is enabled,
tell the compiler to ignore some restrictions and inline the function: add the GNU
extension "__attribute__((always_inline))" to the declaration of the function to be inlined.
Example:
void __attribute__((always_inline)) foo(void);
Note: Validate the results, as inlining can cause performance regressions in some scenarios.

event.name: UNROLL LOOP
event.problem: High branch penalty in a small loop.
event.solution:
Specify the GNU extension "__attribute__ ((optimize ("unroll-loops")))" on the function containing the loop.
Example:
void __attribute__((optimize("unroll-loops"))) foo(void);
Note: Unrolling loops can sometimes negatively impact performance, so validation of its impact is recommended.

event.name: DIRECT TOC ACCESS
event.problem: Data cache pressure is caused by TOC-load instructions.

event.name: REDUCE FOR EARLY EXIT
event.problem: High overhead for function which very frequently returns quickly (e.g. saving registers that are not changed before returning).
event.solution: If reasonable, move code up to and including the test and return statement in the called function instead into the calling function.

event.name: MOVE HOT CODE TO COLD AREA
event.problem: Invariant or infrequently executed code found within a loop.
event.solution: Move the flagged code outside the loop.

event.name: FIX LOAD-HIT-STORE
event.problem: A data store operation followed closely by a load from the same address causes the load to take extra time to complete.

event.name: DE-VIRTUALIZE FUNCTION CALL
event.problem: Indirect function calls (virtual functions or by function pointers) will have higher overhead than direct function calls.
event.solution:
1) Consider making implicated virtual functions non-virtual, if possible. Or, similarly make calls through function pointers into direct calls, if possible.
2) Use both "-flto" and "-O3" flag when compiling the program.
Note: Link-time optimization (-flto) can sometimes negatively impact performance, so validation of its impact is recommended.

event.name: SHORTCUT PLT CALL
event.problem:
Call-through-PLT to local procedure has high call overhead.
A call to a function which is contained in the same object is routed indirectly through the Procedure Linkage Table (PLT). This is normal, to allow for symbols being overridden within the process. However, it is more expensive than a direct call.
event.solution:
1) Use "-Bsymbolic" flag during linking. (Use "-Wl,-Bsymbolic" if using the compiler command, like "gcc" to link.)
2) Use "__attribute__ ((visibility("hidden")))" on both function declaration and in the extern function prototype in header. This allows internal callers to avoid the PLT stub, while still allowing external access to the API.

event.name: EXTSW INSTRUCTION
event.problem: A frequently encountered conversion of a signed 32-bit integer type (int) to a signed 64-bit integer type (long), possibly implicitly, requires an extra "sign extension" instruction which can also delay subsequent dependent instructions.
event.solution: Consider changing the type of source operand to "long".

event.name: FMRTOXXLOR
event.problem: High latency of the FMR/FPR instruction.
event.solution: Use the latest version of the Advance Toolchain or IBM XL compilers, use full optimization (-O3), and tune for the target processor, if possible (e.g. -mcpu=power8).

event.name: XSCPSGNDPXXLOR
event.problem: High latency of the Xscpsgndp instruction.
event.solution: Use the latest version of the Advance Toolchain or IBM XL compilers, use full optimization (-O3), and tune for the target processor, if possible (e.g. -mcpu=power8).

event.name: TARGET TO SOURCE DEPENDENT INSTRUCTIONS
event.problem: Sequence of dependent instructions is not optimal.
event.solution:
1) Use the latest version of the Advance Toolchain or IBM XL compilers, use full optimization (-O3), and tune for the target processor, if possible (e.g. -mcpu=power8).
2) Consider using the integrated sim_ppc tool for pipeline analysis.

event.name: INT TO FLOAT CONVERSION
event.solution: If the conversion is necessary (can't be removed or mitigated by code changes), make sure to use the latest version of the Advance Toolchain or IBM XL compilers, use full optimization (-O3), and tune for the target processor, if possible (e.g. -mcpu=power8).

event.name: LOADING FROM A CONST AREA
event.problem: High penalty for loading from a const area.
event.solution: Use the latest version of the Advance Toolchain or IBM XL compilers, use full optimization (-O3), and tune for the target processor, if possible (e.g. -mcpu=power8).

event.name: BRANCH PREDICTION
event.problem: High penalty for wrong branch prediction.
event.solution: Use the latest version of the Advance Toolchain or IBM XL compilers, use full optimization (-O3), and tune for the target processor, if possible (e.g. -mcpu=power8).

event.name: KILLED REGISTERS
event.problem: High penalty for stores and restores of registers that are killed (overwritten) after frequently executed function calls.
event.solution:
Enable compiler optimization, if not already enabled. If optimization is enabled, tell the compiler to ignore some restrictions and inline the function: add the GNU extension "__attribute__((always_inline))" to the declaration of the function to be inlined.
Example:
void __attribute__((always_inline)) foo(void);
Note: Validate the results, as inlining can cause performance regressions in some scenarios.

event.name: LINK REGISTER OPTIMIZATION
event.problem: High penalty for saves and restores of the link register in frequently-executed functions.
event.solution:
Enable compiler optimization, if not already enabled. If optimization is enabled, trying to inline small functions may help. Add "inline" to the function declaration, or tell the compiler to ignore some restrictions and inline the function: add the GNU extension "__attribute__((always_inline))" to the declaration of the function to be inlined.
Example:
void __attribute__((always_inline)) foo(void);
Note: Validate the results, as inlining can cause performance regressions in some scenarios.

event.name: TOC STORE IN LOOP OPTIMIZATION
event.problem: High penalty for TOC store in loop operation.
event.solution:
1) Add the GNU extension "__attribute__ ((__target__ ("save-toc-indirect")))" to the declaration of the function.
2) Use "-msave-toc-indirect" flag when compiling the program.
Note: It is generally advisable to limit the scope of "-msave-toc-indirect" to the functions which need it (by using the function __attribute__), or only to the source file(s) in which the function(s) which need it reside, as it could cause performance regressions in more general scenarios.
